Name: Amy Klobuchar
Description: Minneapolis, Minnesota. Current senator for Minnesota.
Education: As a senator, Klobuchar has focused on expanding opportunities in higher education, especially in community colleges and vocational schools. Her presidential platform includes tuition-free associate degrees from one- or two year community colleges.
Health: If elected president, Klobuchar plans to cut healthcare costs by: allowing people to buy into affordable insurance through Medicare or Medicaid, protecting low premiums, passing laws allowing drug price negotiation, regulating pharmaceutical companies and implementing mental health and addiction treatment programs.
Immigration: Klobuchar’s plan includes supporting the Dream Act and maintaining border security. She wants to develop a more efficient path to citizenship for many undocumented immigrants and increase levels of legal immigration.
Environment: As part of her ‘100 Days Plan,’ Klobuchar would pass legislation requiring a net emissions-free economy no later than 2050. She also plans to restore the fuel economy standards in the automobile industry from before the Trump Administration.
Gun_Control: Klobuchar wants to implement gun control measures such as background checks, closing various legal loopholes and extending a ban on assault weapons. Much of these changes are included in her ‘100 Day’ plan, including establishing gun violence as a national health problem.

Name: Andrew Yang
Description: New York. Former CEO of Manhattan Prep (education company), founder of Venture for America. The stand-out priority on Yang’s platform is what he calls the “Freedom Dividend” — a universal basic income of $1,000 a month for all American adults, “no strings attached,” paid for with a tax on companies benefiting from automation.
Education: Yang wants to reduce the cost of higher education, including making community college at least nearly tuition-free. He plans to develop vocational programs and wants to invest in a more affordable early childhood care system.
Health: Yang is a proponent of Medicare for All. He believes healthcare should be accessible to all, regardless of employment status. Noting mounting rates of suicide, depression and anxiety, he wants to expand mental health resources and destigmatize getting help.
Immigration: Yang aims to create a way for law-abiding undocumented immigrants to become citizens within their first 18 years in the US. His goal is to create a system that “reflects the fact that they entered the country illegally.” He wants to work with experts and immigration advocates to improve security at the Southern Border, supports the Dream Act and wants to expand skill-based visa programs to attract dedicated students from around the world.
Environment: To combat climate change, Yang plans to implement fees on fossil fuel emissions, invest in technology to reverse pollution, and focus on modernizing infrastructure nationwide. He also wants to protect waterways and national parks to preserve national resources in their “pristine condition.”
Gun_Control: Yang has advocated for a stricter renewable gun licensing process, which includes a thorough background check and safety classes. Yang’s gun safety platform includes explicit mental health resources including “mindfulness programs in schools and correctional facilities” designed to reduce violent behavior.

Name: Bernie Sanders
Description: Burlington, Vermont. Former mayor of Burlington and congressman from Vermont, current senator from Vermont.
Education: Sanders plans to pass the College for All Act, which would invest $48 billion dollars to create a tuition-free public university and community college system. If elected, he would both cancel the current $1.6 trillion dollars in student loan debt and require states to pay for the remaining costs of higher education to make college debt-free. He also wants to promote HBCUs and MSIs as well as support low-income and marginalized students in pursuing higher education.
Health: Sanders proposed the Medicare for All plan in 2017 and 2019, legislation which has since become a political litmus test in the 2020 healthcare debate. His bill outlines a single-payer healthcare program that would eliminate private insurance companies. His platform also includes a plan to cut medication costs in half by aligning prices to those of five other countries and allowing inexpensive prescription drug imports for patients and medical providers.
Immigration: Sanders wants to reverse Trump’s current immigration policies (specifically family separation), reform the path towards citizenship to make it faster and easier, and expand DACA.
Environment: Sanders’ platform includes implementing the controversial Green New Deal, designed to address both the climate crisis and the workers who could lose their jobs because of decarbonization. He wants 100% renewable energy by 2030 and a decarbonized country by 2050, and plans to invest $16.3 trillion towards these efforts while creating 20 million jobs in the process.
Gun_Control: In order to reduce gun violence in the United States, Sanders plans to end the sale of assault weapons to civilians. He plans to make the gun licensing process more rigid, such as developing more expansive background checks and cracking down on gun shows.

Name: Beto O’Rourke
Description: El Paso, Texas. Represented Texas’ 16th congressional district, recently ran for senator against popular incumbent Ted Cruz.
Education: O’Rourke wants to increase teacher salaries to strengthen the pre-k through 12th grade public school system. He also plans to make community college completely free, implement loan-forgiveness programs and create a debt-free higher education option for lower- and middle-income students.
Health: O’Rourke wants to create universal, quality healthcare by lowering out of pocket costs and medication prices. He plans to make Medicare an option but not eliminate private insurance.
Immigration: O’Rourke wants to help create an earned pathway to citizenship for undocumented residents as well as immediately walk back Trump’s family separation policy to reunite all separated families. He’s also a strong proponent of asylum law.
Environment: He plans on investing $5 trillion towards developing a climate-friendly economy and infrastructure, as well as taking immediate executive action towards preventing further pollution. O’Rourke aims to have net-zero carbon emissions by the year 2050.
Gun_Control: O’Rourke’s gun control platform explicitly calls for combatting white supremacist violence and hate crimes, forces behind the mass shooting in his hometown of El Paso, Texas. He wants to stop online radicalization and treat similar shootings as domestic terrorism. He also wants to stop selling automatic and military grade weapons, implement gun licenses that require background checks and assessment by law enforcement, and declare gun violence a public health emergency.

Name: Bill de Blasio
Description: New York City. Former campaign manager for Hillary Clinton, current mayor of New York City
Education: One main accomplishment during his tenure as mayor of NYC was implementing a program that allowed all four-year-olds access to public pre-K. He also recently reached an agreement with the Union Federation of Teachers, granting a renewed contract to 129,000 educators.
Health: In January 2019, Bill de Blasio announced a citywide universal healthcare program that would provide coverage to over 600,000 New Yorkers. His plan would include mental health and addiction services, making it one of the most comprehensive municipal health care plans in the country.
Immigration: De Blasio has clashed with Trump over NYC’s status as a sanctuary city, and previously called Trump’s Muslim ban “un-American.” His universal healthcare plan also included undocumented immigrants, making him one of the few mayors to grant this demographic public insurance.
Environment: In the wake of Hurricane Sandy and the daunting UN Climate report, de Blasio has announced a plan to protect Manhattan against rising sea levels — including to expand the island by 500 feet along the lower coastline — which would cost up to $10 billion. He has also warned the Trump Organization that, if they don’t reduce their carbon emissions by 2030, they could be fined up to $2.1 million annually. However, he’s received criticism from progressive voters for not yet signing NYC’s version of the Green New Deal, a contentious issue in the 2020 race.
Gun_Control: De Blasio is praised for his work in reducing the crime rate in NYC, especially around guns: in 2016, the city saw their lowest number of shootings in over 30 years. His current gun safety initiatives center around community law enforcement and organizations, as well as encouraging New Yorkers to promote gun control in their own neighborhoods.

Name: Cory Booker
Description: Newark, New Jersey. Former Mayor of Newark, current junior Senator from New Jersey.
Education: Booker has expressed support for affordable education from pre-K to college and wants universal early childhood education. He is a major proponent of student services and added an amendment to the No Child Left Behind bill that focuses on support for foster children and homeless youth.
Health: Booker supports “quality, affordable and universal health care” and co-sponsored Bernie Sanders’ ‘Medicare for All” bill. His policy includes implementing Medicare for All, but in the meantime would expand the income limits to ensure more lower- and middle-income seniors access to healthcare. To address the opioid crisis, Booker plans to “treat addiction like a disease.” He also has plans to lower prescription drug prices.
Immigration: In 2018, Booker drafted legislation in 2018 against the child separations and plans to continue to protect Dreamers. His policy plan includes ending ICE raids in schools and medical facilities, expanding legal immigration aid and addressing the primary reasons refugees migrate to the US, especially in Latin America, the Middle East, Africa and the Carribean.
Environment: Booker’s climate policy includes rejoining the Paris Climate Accord, signing the Green New Deal and emphasizing environmental justice by growing the EPA’s civil rights-centered programs. His plan focuses on major oil corporations and aims to ban fracking and crude oil export. Booker is one of the only candidates who includes animal rights in his presidential platform. He plans to implement protections on endangered species and to restore millions of acres of wildlife ecosystems.
Gun_Control: In 2017, Booker introduced a bill banning assault weapons. His current platform includes implementing universal background checks and gun licences, increasing regulations on major gun manufacturers and limiting gun purchases.

Name: Elizabeth Warren
Description: Cambridge, Massachusetts. Current senator from Massachusetts.
Education: Warren helped introduce a 2017 bill that would make public US colleges mostly tuition free, and detailed her plan to make public higher education free and enact cancel loan debt for 95 percent of current debt holders. She also supports universal child care and wants to partner with licensed care centers that would operate under federal standards.
Health: During the July debates, Warren said she supports Medicare for all alongside Bernie Sanders. She says she wants to fight the current private insurance model that benefits from increasing copays and premiums as well as denying clients with important medical care. Single-payer healthcare, she says, will stop the insurance industry from controlling the cost of vital treatment. She’s also backed a number of other policies that would cut healthcare costs, including one that would limit insurer profits.
Immigration: As part of her immigration platform, Warren plans to rebuild ICE and CBP “from top to bottom,” including focusing the organizations on transparency and the prevention of human rights abuses. She also plans to increase the refugee limit over five fold in her first year, streamline the asylum process and develop a clear path to citizenship.
Environment: Warren’s climate change plan includes developing a net-zero emissions economy by 2030, adopting former candidate Jay Inslee’s plan for clean energy. This includes investing 1.5 trillion in American-made renewable energy products to jumpstart a climate friendly economy at a state and federal level. In the past, she has advocated for a rule requiring public companies to report emissions.
Gun_Control: In 2019, Warren cosponsored a bill to ban assault weapons alongside many other high-profile Democratic senators. Her gun control plan will require states to report gun owners with multiple purchases, investigating the NRA and similar lobbyist organizations, instituting universal background checks, and implementing a federal license system.

Name: Eric Swalwell
Description: Dublin, California. Current congressman for California’s 15th congressional district, former prosecutor for Alameda County.
Education: Swalwell has introduced numerous pieces of legislation that support debt-free college and no-interest student loans. Recently proposed a “college bargain” system, in which students would pay for school through a series of work-study programs.
Health: Published op-ed in support of Medicare-for-All, also co-sponsored a Medicare bill in February 2019. Wants coverage for all, but doesn’t want to get rid of private insurance.
Immigration: In the past, Swalwell has shown support for bipartisan immigration measures and protecting ‘Dreamers’. More recently, he’s been an open critic of Trump’s immigration approach, saying it lacks “compassion.”
Environment: Recently advocated for AOC’s Green New Deal in the House, and was vocal about his opposition to Trump pulling out of Paris Agreement.
Gun_Control: Has co-sponsored a number of gun-related bills, and supports banning assault weapons and starting a federal buy-back program. He also has tried to keep them away from people with histories of domestic assault.

Name: Jay Inslee
Description: Seattle, Washington area. Former congressman from Washington’s 4th congressional district, current governor of Washington.
Education: As governor, Inslee has advocated for early childhood education, school health and safety, and more concrete paths for graduates to enter the workforce. His most recent budget has dedicated funding towards teachers and school counselors.
Health: In the 2019 legislative session, Inslee signed a law that would make it the first state to offer a comprehensive public insurance plan by 2021. The bill is a combination of a private and public healthcare system, and would provide insurance to all Washingtonians.
Immigration: Inslee has condemned Trump for his “bombastic” immigration policy, and thinks that addressing pollution will help decrease immigration into the US, which he attributes in part to climate change refugees.
Environment: Climate change reversal is Inslee’s flagship issue; he describes his campaign as “a new American climate change mission.” He co-authored a book in 2007 that advocated for a new economy based on clean energy, and has written legislation to back up his proposals. He also created the Clean Energy Fund and co-founded the US Climate Alliance. For 2020, his goal is 100 percent clean energy by 2030, which involved reducing pollution from each part of the US economy.
Gun_Control: In 1994, Inslee took a strong stance on gun control by backing legislation that would ban the manufacturing and sale of assault-style weapons, a position that made him unpopular in the 1995 elections. He has maintained these attitudes about gun control during his tenure as governor, banning bump stocks and fixing background check loopholes.

Name: Joe Biden
Description: Wilmington, Delaware. Former Senator from Delaware and Former Vice President of the United States.
Education: Biden proposes to increase teacher salaries and double the number of school psychologists, guidance counselors, nurses, social workers and other support staff. He also supports universal pre-kindergarten for all 3- and 4-year olds and vocational training for high school students.
Health: As a former member of the Obama administration, Biden is a strong proponent of the Affordable Care Act. On his website, he outlines a plan to maintain the Affordable Care Act, expand coverage to low-income Americans and give Americans a “new choice,” a public health insurance plan option like Medicare. Biden's campaign site implies that he does not support single-payer health care.
Immigration: Biden has been a vocal critic of the Trump Administration’s plan to build a wall and treatment of DREAMers. On his campaign website, he cites immigration as the way America “has been able to constantly renew and reinvent itself” and says he wants to continue his work under Obama to address issues that sparked the recent waves of immigration.
Environment: Biden has received a lifetime score of 83% from the League of Conservation Voters, one of the worst scores for the Democratic contenders. He’s also received criticism from notable progressives such as Alexandria Ocasio Cortez who have scrutinized his climate control approach as too “middle-of-the-road.” Biden’s current plan is more progressive, however, and includes a goal to be net emission-free by 2050, infrastructure investments, and environmental justice initiatives to take down major polluters that disproportionately harm low-income and communities of color.
Gun_Control: Biden voted for a bill that would restrict semiautomatic weapon ownership in 1993 and expressed support for an assault weapon ban after the 2015 Pulse nightclub shooting in Orlando. On his website, he promises to fight back against the National Rifle Association (NRA) and push for legislation to ban assault weapons and high-capacity magazines.

Name: Joe Sestak
Description: Delaware County, Pennsylvania. Former navy admiral, congressman for Pennsylvania’s 7th congressional district, and professor.
Education: Sestak plans to implement a public pre-K system for children ages 4 and up and incentivize universities to keep tuition low with federal loans. Instead of relying on standardized tests, he also wants to assess school performance by a national Common Core Standard, which would provide educational benchmarks for each grade level that all students should meet.
Health: Sestak says he wants to implement a universal healthcare system, and is considering two options: Medicare for All and a system modeled after the Veterans Health Administration, where medical services would be directly provided by the government. He also aims to focus on mental health care and lower drug prices by allowing public healthcare to negotiate directly with pharmaceutical companies.
Immigration: Sestak wants to create a strict path to citizenship for undocumented residents in the US and end Trump’s family separation policy. He also wants to increase visa caps, especially for STEM students and skilled workers.
Environment: Sestak aims to reduce carbon emissions to net-zero by 2050 and wants to implement a tax on each ton of carbon emitted by major corporations. He also wants to rejoin the Paris Climate accord and says he will fight to protect forests and other natural habitats, especially National Monuments.
Gun_Control: On his campaign website, Sestak says he wants to focus on securing universal background checks and tightening loopholes, including ones that permit the sale of easily-assembled firearm parts without a background check. He also wants to allow the CDC to treat gun violence as a public health risk and make recommendations on how to decrease fatalities.

Name: John Delaney
Description: Montgomery County, Maryland. Congressman for Maryland’s 6th congressional district.
Education: In 2017, Delaney introduced a bill that would guarantee pre-K education — he wants the current system that guarantees K-12 education to be extended to pre-K and two years of community college or vocational school. He also plans to make higher education more affordable by reducing student loans and focusing grant funds on low-income families.
Health: Delaney has his own proposal for universal healthcare, but differentiates it from Medicare-for-all. Rather than completely getting rid of private healthcare, he plans to introduce a new public insurance option for Americans under age 65 similar to Obamacare, after which they would switch to Medicare.
Immigration: If elected president, Delaney promises an immigration reform plan that would both invest in border security and create a concrete path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants.
Environment: Delaney has a 94% scorecard from the League of Conservation Voters, and, if elected president, plans to rejoin the Paris Climate Accord on day one of his tenure. He also plans to pass a bipartisan carbon tax, invest $5 billion in technology designed to remove carbon emissions, and establish nationwide sustainable infrastructure.
Gun_Control: Delaney earned a 7 percent scorecard from the NRA, ranking him alongside Kamala Harris and Cory Booker. His platform includes investing in federal gun violence research, a ban on semiautomatic weapons and implementing extreme risk laws to remove firearms from at-risk individuals.

Name: John Hickenlooper
Description: Denver, Colorado. Former mayor of Denver, current governor of Colorado.
Education: As the mayor of Denver, Hickenlooper implemented a citywide scholarship fund to help low-income students pay for college. His tenure as governor, however, began during the Recession, leading his administration to cut $332 million in education funding — a decision he later expressed regret for.
Health: As governor, Hickenlooper implemented an expansion of Obamacare that offered healthcare to 160,000 low income Colorado residents. However, in 2016, he disavowed a single-payer healthcare system, and that while he supports the concept, he doesn’t think it makes practical sense.
Immigration: In 2018, Hickenlooper signed an executive order that prevented Colorado’s statewide resources from being used to further the Trump Administration’s family separation policy. He has also expressed support for the protection of DREAMers.
Environment: Hickenlooper recently wrote an op-ed for the Washington Post voicing his disapproval for the Green New Deal. However, as a former geologists, he has been a staunch advocate for reducing carbon emissions and added Colorado to the US Climate Alliance as governor.
Gun_Control: During his tenure as governor of Colorado, a shooting occurred in Aurora, Colorado. He responded with a series of major gun control bills that expanded background checks and limits on ammunition magazines. His hard position on gun control became one of his signature acts as governor.

Name: Julian Castro
Description: San Antonio, Texas. Former mayor of San Antonio, Obama’s Secretary of Housing and Development.
Education: Castro plans to implement universal pre-K program for 3- and 4-year-olds, invest in educational technology, expand dual enrollment and early college programs in high schools and make all public colleges and universities tuition-free. He also wants to increase teachers’ annual salaries.
Health: In the second Democratic debate, Castro said he wants “to strengthen Medicare for the people who are on it and then expand it to anybody who wants it” and end pharmaceutical companies’ strong hold on drug prices. However, he believes in keeping a private option open for those who plan to stay with current providers.
Immigration: Castro wants to create a clear, concrete path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants and DACA recipients, and wants to increase the number of refugees admitted into the US. He also plans to end ICE detainers and overhaul the current visa program, which includes eliminating the backlog of people waiting for visas and limits based on country of origin.
Environment: Castro wants to create a net-zero emissions country by 2045, lowering pollution to at least half of 2005 emissions levels before 2030. His platform is largely focused on environmental justice and includes laws that would force federal agencies to consider their health impact on marginalized communities. He wants to hold perpetrators accountable for environmental discrimination through the EPA’s Civil Rights office.
Gun_Control: Castro’s platform on gun control includes universal background checks. He wants to protect domestic violence victims by closing the “boyfriend” loophole, strengthen gun licensing processes by closing the “private sale” loophole and implement a seven day waiting period before all firearms sales. To fight domestic terrorism and nationalism, Castro plans to create the White House Initiative on Disarming Hate with at least $100 million of annual funding to combat hate crimes.

Name: Kamala Harris
Description: Los Angeles, California. Former attorney general of California, current senator from California.
Education: In 2017, Harris co-sponsored Senator Bernie Sanders’ bill on affordable higher education — the College for All act — which aimed to provide tuition grants for families that make less than $125,000 annually. Her presidential platform on education includes tuition-free community college, debt-free four-year college and income boosts to Pell Grant recipients through her LIFT Act.
Health: Harris has been a strong supporter of the Affordable Care Act and Sanders’ Medicare-for-All bill. She plans to create a 10-year phase-in period, during which all newborns and the uninsured would be automatically enrolled in public healthcare, while leaving the option for insurance companies to create federally-regulated Medicare options. She has also taken steps to support mental health care and cut maternal mortality rates.
Immigration: If elected president, Harris vows to overturn President Donald Trump’s infamous Muslim Ban, shut down private immigrant detention centers and fix the current overflow of visa requests, especially those in the family visa program, as soon as possible. She also wants to streamline the citizenship process by assisting DACA recipients as they apply for green cards.
Environment: Harris’ climate plan includes achieving a net-zero emission economy by 2030 and investing $10 trillion in transportation, water and energy infrastructure.
Gun_Control: Harris supports comprehensive background checks and a ban on assault weapons. As the attorney general of California, she organized a statewide sweep of illegally owned firearms in which 1,200 weapons were confiscated. She also wants to close the "boyfriend loophole" to protect domestic assault survivors and end gun sales to criminals with outstanding arrest warrants.

Name: Kirsten Gillibrand
Description: Brunswick, New York. Senator from New York.
Education: Gillibrand has advocated for STEM education, decreasing teacher retention rates, and improving childhood education through accts such as the Head Start program. She also cosponsored an act that would help organizations in low-income areas give tuition grants to make higher education more affordable.
Health: Gillibrand was one of the original cosponsors of Medicare For All, and has long been a proponent of accessible, high-quality healthcare.
Immigration: Gillibrand has faced criticism for her contradicting track immigration track record: while she once advocated for increased deportation rates and making English the official language in the US, she has recently called to abolish ICE.
Environment: She has vocally supported the “framework” of the Green New Deal, and has served on the Senate Environment & Public Works committee. She wants the US to become a global leader in green technology and a sustainable economy.
Gun_Control: As a congresswoman, Gillibrand received an “A” from the NRA. However, she has become more liberal around gun control after the Sandy Hook Elementary School Shooting in 2012, and wrote any op-ed about gun safety following the tragedy. Her “A” has dropped to an “F” in recent years.

Name: Marianne Williamson
Description: Houston, Texas (currently lives in Frederic, Wisconsin). New York Times bestselling author, lecturer, and has appeared on Oprah.
Education: Williamson supports universal preschool and more funding for free-lunch programs. She also aims to promote more diverse teaching approaches, including social and emotional learning, and teacher retention programs.
Health: Williamson wants to implement universal health care similar to Obamacare while keeping a private insurance option. She also wants to focus on mental health and “lifestyle” services and improve medical technology.
Immigration: Williamson plans to reduce cost of naturalization process, and wants to make the path to citizenship easier and faster (specifically for asylum seekers). She also wants to reduce the number of ICE detainees.
Environment: Williamson wants to mirror California’s current environmental regulations and reach net-zero emission levels by 2045. She also wants to move away from new non-electric vehicles by 2030 and implement the Green New Deal.
Gun_Control: Williamson wants to terminate sale of assault and semi-automatic rifles, ban bump stocks, and require universal background checks for all gun sales. She also plans to allow the CDC to track gun ownership more thoroughly.

Name: Michael Bennet
Description: Denver, Colorado. Former Superintendent to Colorado Public schools, current senator from Colorado.
Education: During his time as Denver’s Superintendent, Bennet was criticized for his decision to shut down struggling schools in the district. He passed legislation in 2015 that repaired the No Child Left Behind bill, and has affirmed his commitment to exceptional, affordable education in his presidential campaign.
Health: Unlike many Democratic 2020 candidates, Bennet is opposed to Medicare-for-All. However, he has proposed a universal health care plan entitled Medicare-X which his campaign website says will lower the cost of prescription drugs, enroll millions more in public healthcare while leaving a private insurance option.
Immigration: One of Bennet’s most famous accomplishments was his role in the Gang of Eight, a group of Senators that proposed a comprehensive, bipartisan immigration bill in 2013 that included a path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants, invested in border control technology, and expanded the US’ visa system.
Environment: Bennet proposed a climate plan that would aim for zero emission in the US by 2050, create 10 million sustainable jobs, promote green technology and infrastructure, and encourage other countries to follow his administration’s example.
Gun_Control: Bennet has a 7 percent rating from the NRA. His campaign website also says he is committed to passing common-sense gun control to stop the “images of violence in our society.”

Name: Pete Buttigieg
Description: South Bend, Indiana. Mayor of South Bend for past eight years, Afghan war veteran
Education: Buttigieg agrees that public tuition should be affordable and free for lower income families. He plans to approach the issue through a state-federal partnership combined with an increase in Pell Grants. He also plans to invest $25 billion in historically black colleges and universities (HBCUs) and minority-serving institutions (MSI).
Health: Buttigieg has outlined his healthcare plan as a gradual Medicare-for-all, or a “Medicare for all who want it.” The plan would include a Medicare type public option and invite people to buy into it. He also plans to prioritize rural America by training homegrown doctors and nurses with an emphasis on primary care, maternal care, mental health and addition providers.
Immigration: Like many Democratic contenders, Buttigieg plans to create a path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants including DREAMers. He also wants an overhaul of current immigration legislation, including ending the family separation crisis and evaluating ICE and the U.S. Customs and Border Protection.
Environment: Buttigieg was one of 407 mayors to commit to the Paris Climate Accord separate from federal policies, and plans to rejoin the agreement if elected president. He says he is committed to implementing the Green New Deal and aims to increase clean energy infrastructure.
Gun_Control: Buttigieg has joined the Mayors Against Illegal Guns coalition, which strives to increase gun safety in cities across America. On his online platform, he has vowed to ban assault weapons and high capacity magazines, institute a national gun licensing system and close various loopholes in existing gun legislation, including those surrounding domestic violence.

Name: Steve Bullock
Description: Helena, Montana. Current Governor of Montana.
Education: Bullock wants to implement tuition-free community college, double the federal education budget for K-12 schools and expand eligibility requirements for Pell Grants. He also plans to emphasize the importance of MSIs and HBCUs by expanding their financial resources.
Health: Bullock wants build on the Affordable Care Act by providing a universal public option and automatically enrolling all eligible families. He also plans to fight pharmaceutical companies on lowering drug prices and limiting out-of-pocket medical expenses.
Immigration: Bullock plans to grant citizenship to DACA recipients, redirect ICE’s mission away from detention centers and invest in organizations in El Salvador, Honduras and Guatemala—addressing much of the root cause of immigration from Latin America. However, he plans on keeping Section 1325, a controversial piece of immigrtion law that makes undocumented immigration a crime.
Environment: Bullock plans to rejoin the Paris Climate Accord as soon as possible, which includes a net-zero emissions goal of 2050. He also wants to update infrastructure to make it more climate friendly, particularly moving towards solar energy and other advanced technologies.
Gun_Control: Bullock has cautiously supported a ban on assault weapons and supports universal background checks. Overall, he’s been moderate on the topic of guns, and wants to find a middle ground between gun ownership and safety.

Name: Tim Ryan
Description: Niles, Ohio. Current congressman for Ohio.
Education: If elected president, Ryan wants to invest $100 billion in school infrastructure, provide tax credits to teachers and other school staff, and promote mental and physical health programs. In 2018, Ryan cosponsored three bills that promoted tuition-free and debt-free college.
Health: Ryan supports Medicare for All, but believes in a more gradual transition. Rather than completely eliminate private insurance, he wants to create a public buy-in option and increase involvement over time.
Immigration: At the June debate, Ryan spoke out against Trump’s treatment of immigrants at the border, saying “ If you go to Guantanamo Bay, there are terrorists that are held that get better healthcare than those kids.” He also said he agreed with Julian Castro and wants to repeal Section 1325, the law makes undocumented immigrantion illegal.
Environment: Ryan wants to reduce carbon emissions by advocating for more widespread use of clean energy sources, and invest in emission-free technology and climate friendly industries. He would also rejoin the Paris Climate accord.
Gun_Control: At the June debate, Ryan said he supports gun reform in relation to school shootings, as well as mental health and trauma care to prevent further incidents.

Name: Tom Steyer
Description: San Francisco, California. Founder of NextGen America, billionaire and impeachment advocate.
Education: Steyer describes education as one of five rights critical to every American and on his campaign website implies support for tuition-free education from preschool through college or vocational training.
Health: Universal healthcare is another of Steyer’s five fundamental rights and one of the primary issues his organization advocates for. He posted a petition on his website that says Trump is “intentionally sabotaging any chance of affordable healthcare for working families.” In 2017, he told the Atlantic he thought Sanders’ single payer healthcare plan was not realistic but a goal Congress should aim for.
Immigration: NextGen America’s website describes immigrants as having made crucial contributions to the US economy and society and suggests they need a more direct path to citizenship. In 2018, Steyer announced he would invest one million dollars into the immigrants rights community intended to decrease deportations. When talking to press afterwards, he condemned Trump for his family separation policy.
Environment: Climate justice as a focal point of Steyers’ campaign. His plan involves rejoining the Paris Climate Accord, creating sustainable jobs, building climate-friendly infrastructure and implementing a community-centric climate justice programs. Steyer’s foundation NextGen America is largely centered on climate advocacy.
Gun_Control: In the wake of the Marjory Stoneman Douglas school shooting, Steyer posted a Facebook video where he condemned Trump for his gun control policies and disavowed politicians who accepted money from the NRA. NextGen America partnered with Everytown for Gun Safety to implement a program that encouraged high school students to vote.

Name: Tulsi Gabbard
Description: Honolulu, Hawaii. Currently serves in Congress representing Hawaii.
Education: Gabbard says she supports Senator Bernie Sanders’ College For All Act, which aims to make higher education more affordable. She has advocated for STEAM education and teacher flexibility during her congressional tenure. She also supported the Private Student Loan Bankruptcy Fairness Act, introduced in 2015, to eliminate debt without proof of undue burden. She says on her website that she wants to invest in education and therefore our future.
Health: Gabbard supports Medicare for all but argues that even universal healthcare doesn’t go far enough. She intends to address the cost of prescription medication and invest in preventative care.
Immigration: Gabbard has been an avid supporter of DACA recipients in the past and cosponsored both the Dream Act and a bill protecting DREAMers from deportation during DACA hearings. She has been outspoken against Trump’s immigration policies and his use of young immigrants as a bargaining chip in policy debates.
Environment: Gabbard says she plans to create incentives for 100% renewable energy sources and will move to end subsidies for the nuclear power industry. She supports a ban on fracking and has cosponsored bills to ban dangerous pesticides, stop the use of fossil fuels and increase water access in disadvantaged communities. She has been endorsed the Maui Sierra Club and has a 96% lifetime scorecard from the League of Conservation Voters.
Gun_Control: Gabbard cosponsored several gun control bills, including legislation focused on regulating assault weapons and bump stocks and closing loopholes for domestic abusers. However, many consider her push for gun control as lacking compared to Democrat counterparts.

Name: Wayne Messam
Description: Miramar, Florida. Current Mayor of Miramar, former entrepreneur.
Education: In order to spark growth in the economy and help reduce the cost of education, Messam has proposed a $1.5 trillion debt-cancellation program that would help one in four Americans with student loans. He also wants to raise teacher salaries and invest in classroom resources.
Health: Messam says he wants to lower drug costs if elected, and plans to allow the federal government to negotiate drug prices with pharmaceutical companies. Of the cost of drugs such as insulin, Messam said, “It’s reprehensible that in the world’s wealthiest country, some are dying because they cannot afford the simple injections they need to live.”
Immigration: As mayor of Miramar, Messam partnered with the Florida Immigrant Coalition and United We Dream to create support resources for immigrants in his community, including legal aide and city-wide ID cards. He also passed a resolution demanding ICE to improve conditions at a local immigration check-in office.
Environment: Messam says he plans to “lead the world and take bold, direct, climate action that will rival the New Deal” within his first ten years. He heavily criticized Trump for pulling out of the Paris Climate Accord.
Gun_Control: Messam, along with a group of Florida mayors, sued Gov. Rick Scott after the Parkland shooting for a state law that restricts municipal gun control measures. He also passed a bill to close various gun purchase loopholes and expand background checks, which he says he wants to continue on a federal level if elected president.

Name: William Weld
Description: Massachusetts. Former governor of Massachusetts and federal prosecutor.
Education: One solution Weld has proposed is a stronger focus on online education, which he suggests could help working families access higher education.
Health: As the governor of Massachusetts, Weld requested additional Medicare funding from the federal government and later loosened requirements to receive public insurance.
Immigration: Weld disavowed Trump’s border wall as a “political shibboleth” and compared his immigration policies to Nazi Germany.
Environment: Despite his spot on the GOP ticket, Weld expressed support for the Paris Climate Accord and believes the US should rejoin.
Gun_Control: Although he was a Libertarian as recently as 2016, Weld a mixed record on gun control: he proposed a statewide ban on assault weapons in 1993, and also tried to rise the legal gun ownership age to 21.
